awd_titl_txt: New Extensions to Symmetry-adapted Perturbation Theory: Spin Splittings, Explicitly Correlated Dispersion, and Intramolecular Interactions
awd_abstract_narration:
Professor Konrad Patkowski of Auburn University is supported by an award from the Chemical Theory, Models, and Computational Methods program in the Division of Chemistry to develop new computational methods that extend the capabilities of calculating weak interaction energies between molecules. These methods combine high accuracy with interpretive power, providing insight into the physical origins of interactions between molecules. This kind of insight is aids in the understanding, simulation, and rational design of interactions that play key roles in chemistry, physics, biochemistry, and materials science. The new methods developed by Patkowski and his group, which are being implemented in an open-source computer program, are useful for describing interactions relevant to atmospheric chemistry, molecular magnetism, and transition metal catalysis. They also provide a new route to quantifying and interpreting interactions between different fragments of the same molecule, such as those that control the three-dimensional structure of proteins and nucleic acids. In addition, Patkowski continues to develop hands-on computational chemistry modules within the framework of the Auburn University Summer Science Institute, providing realistic research experiences to high-school students and enhancing their awareness of careers in science. He is also facilitating course redesign workshops for Auburn University faculty to facilitate active learning techniques into their classes.

The approaches developed by Professor Patkowski and his group extend the symmetry-adapted perturbation theory (SAPT) method for calculating interaction energies between molecules in terms of electrostatic, induction, dispersion, and exchange interactions. In its most common closed-shell formulation, SAPT is widely used to construct intermolecular potential energy surfaces, interpret, and compare the origins of bonding for different complexes and structures, and aid in the construction of force fields. Patkowski is developing three new approaches that enhance the basis set convergence of existing SAPT treatments through an explicitly correlated framework.  This will extend the method to complexes in low-spin states by building explicit spin-flip excitations into the exchange energy expressions, and open up a new avenue of application to intramolecular noncovalent interactions, based on range separation of the Coulomb potential rather than fragmentation of the system. Applications of the newly constructed SAPT variants include the elucidation of spin splittings in organic ferromagnets, radical cation-radical anion interactions, and pancake-bonded dimers, the refinement of benchmark energy component databases for force field fitting and classification of complexes according to interaction types.  This enables the quantitative description of intramolecular interactions responsible for the stability of sterically crowded molecules and the conformational profiles of molecular balances.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
There are many reasons why scientists are interested in weak interactions between atoms and molecules. The tiny attraction between helium atoms is the only reason why helium becomes liquid at temperatures close to absolute zero, and a little stronger attraction between sucrose molecules keeps a sugar crystal together. The same kind of interactions shows up in biochemistry, deciding the secondary and tertiary structure of proteins and the binding of drug molecules to their target in the body. Therefore, calculating small energetic changes due to intermolecular interactions is an important task.

Why do molecules interact without forming chemical bonds? Polar systems exhibit dipole-dipole forces that favor one intermolecular orientation over another. Molecule A can polarize molecule B, inducing some temporary dipole moment, and B can do the same to A. The motion of electrons in two chemical systems becomes correlated, giving rise to attractive London dispersion forces. Finally, exchange repulsion prevents two molecules from coming too close together. With all these distinct physical effects contributing to the interaction, it is crucial to design computational chemistry methods that provide more than a single number, giving us insights into the nature of a particular interaction.

Symmetry-adapted perturbation theory (SAPT) is such a method, combining accurate total interaction energies with their decomposition into physically meaningful quantities corresponding to the different aspects of interaction listed above. It is a mature approach and several efficient computer codes can calculate the SAPT energy contributions for typical intermolecular complexes. At the same time, new enhancements to SAPT are an active research area, and our group has been working on further SAPT development.

In the course of this award, we have derived, programmed, and tested several new variants that make SAPT more robust, more accurate, and more computationally efficient:

  • An interaction between two open-shell molecules may lead to a bunch of different spin states of the complex. The description of all these states on an equal footing is vital for spectroscopy. However, many quantum chemistry methods including standard SAPT can only access the high-spin state of the system. We are developing the first variant of SAPT which can compute interaction energies in all spin-states of the complex, providing researchers with simple and meaningful estimates of spin splittings.
  • The accuracy of a quantum-chemistry energy calculation is determined by both the level of theory (the quality of approximation to the true solution of the Schrodinger equation) and the basis set used to expand molecular orbitals. Unfortunately, accurate theories  lead to slow basis set convergence. We proposed a computationally efficient algorithm to compute the most important dispersion contributions in an explicitly correlated manner, leading to drastically improved basis set performance - results in small basis sets are already close to converged.
  • Interactions between non-connected groups in the same molecule are fundamentally no different from interactions between separate molecules. However, the theory of such intramolecular interactions is much less developed because one needs to decide how to split the molecule into fragments. The original intramolecular SAPT (ISAPT) approach sometimes give results that do not make sense, such as a repulsive electrostatic interaction in an intramolecular hydrogen-bonded system. We identified the source of this problem as unphysical dipole moments at the boundaries between molecular fragments, and proposed an alternative algorithm where those dipoles are significantly reduced. We found that the improved ISAPT variant gives physically meaningful energies for any fragmentation pattern, and we used it to provide insight into several chemically interesting systems including molecular balances. We are also trying to develop an intramolecular SAPT theory that does not involve molecular fragmentation at all - instead, we split the interaction potential into long and short range. We recently tested the SAPT and ISAPT performance with the purely long-range potential and confirmed that it can account for nearly the entire noncovalent interaction.

The new methods and algorithms developed by our group make their way into the Psi4 open-source quantum chemistry software, and several of our new SAPT variants are already available in the public release of Psi4.

There are several ways in which the PI and his group use their research to create opportunities for engaging a broader community in Alabama and beyond. The group takes part in the Auburn University Summer Science Institute for high schoolers, where we created an interactive quantum chemistry module complete with short group projects using the WebMO interface as a front end to Gaussian calculations. We contribute to the training and education resources accompanying the Psi4 code, developing Psi4NumPy tutorials and Psi4Education class modules. Another interactive tutorial, on SAPT, was taught to the members of the Phymol European Doctoral Network and is available on YouTube. Finally, the PI has embraced active learning, both in his own classes (including a newly developed course on Python programming in chemistry) and as a facilitator for faculty active learning workshops at Auburn University.
